title: BHP to slash 380 jobs at SA mine
text:
Mon, Aug 10, 2015, 6:22 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed BHP to slash 380 jobs at SA mine AAP – 1 hour 15 minutes ago Recommend View Photo 

Mining giant BHP Billiton will slash 380 jobs at its Olympic Dam copper and uranium mine, in another blow to South Australia's ailing labour market. 
The cuts build on job losses at Olympic Dam earlier this year and have prompted calls for urgent state government action to stem the tide of unemployment in SA, which is at 7.9 per cent, the highest in the country. 
But businesses and officials in the nearby town of Roxby Downs say the community is resilient and the job losses may serve as a circuit-breaker, allowing locals to look towards a brighter future. 
Roxby Downs Mitre 10 manager Craig Dodman said uncertainty over which jobs would go was crippling the community. 
"Everyone is thinking `Am I one of those 380 people?' So money goes back into the pocket," Mr Dodman told AAP on Monday. 
"So as soon as these cuts are done, it will probably have a positive effect on us." 
Roxby Downs administrator Bill Boehm said locals were well aware a substantial amount of job losses were coming. 
"Difficult though it is, and we're all affected by it, there is both a bright short-term and long-term future," Mr Boehm told ABC radio. 
BHP said its decision to cut jobs was not a reflection of state government policy settings. 
"Instead it is driven by the global challenges in the resources sector and the need to transform Olympic Dam into a sustainable operation that can contribute to the South Australian economy for many years to come," Olympic Dam asset president Jacqui McGill said in a statement. 
The job losses will reduce the total workforce at Olympic Dam to about 3500 and should be finalised by mid-September. 
Following the latest cuts and a decision to mothball a major expansion for the mine, the state government has urged BHP to spell out its long-term plans for Olympic Dam. 
While Opposition Leader Steven Marshall said the latest job losses emphasised the need for the government to urgently boost employment.
